title: DOM
definition: The Document Object Model (DOM) is an interface for interacting with web documents. It provides a hierarchical tree-like structure of objects that represent the elements and content of a web page, including HTML. Developers use JavaScript to interact with and manipulate these objects, enabling dynamic control and modification of web content.

title: Client
definition: Typically, client in web development refers to the software or web browser used to access a website or web app, such as Google Chrome. These make requests to servers to get certain data or resources.

title: Server
definition: A server is a way of storing or managing data and other resources through a physical computer (hardware) or service (software). Clients, most often web browsers, can make fetch and other requests to the server to get the appropriate resources needed. Software includes virtual, cloud-based, or database servers.

title: Client-side/ Server-side
definition: 'Client-side' refers to the underlying code and processes, such as HTML, CSS, and JS, that create the visual and dynamic experience for a user. 'Server-side' in the same way means the underlying code and processes, such as Django, which run on the server. These respond to client requests.

title: Frontend
definition: A general term for the part of a web application that a user interacts with. A visual representation of a website such as images, buttons, navigation that make up the design and functionality.

title: Backend
definition: The backend refers to the entire server-side aspect of a web application that the user does not directly interact with. Including the code that handles client requests, the database, security, API's, and more.

title: Angle bracket uses
definition: These are used to define and enclose HTML tags, an essential feature for web development. Also, in JS they can be used as comparison operators, for instance greater than or less than.

title: CPU
definition: The primary component of a computer. It executes tasks by processing instructions from computer programs. Often referred to as the 'brain', it handles data, runs software, and responds to requests made by the user.

title: API
definition: An API, conceptually, is a set of rules and protocols that define the methods and data formats required for applications to request and exchange information. For example, a web API uses the HTTP protocol to specify methods like 'POST' and 'GET' and often utilizes data formats like JSON to transfer data between clients and servers.

title: CDN
definition: A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a network of distributed servers located around the world. It caches and serves copies of data, including images and other content, from the origin server to various geographic locations.

title: XSS
definition: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) is a type of security vulnerability in web applications where attackers attempt to inject malicious code, often in the form of JavaScript, into the application.

title: CMS
definition: A CMS, or content management system, is a software application that can be run either locally or online, used for creating, managing, and publishing digital content to the internet.

title: GUI
definition: A GUI, or graphical user interface, employs visual elements like buttons, icons, and menus to provide a user-friendly and intuitive way to navigate and interact with software or devices.

title: JSON
definition: JavaScript Object Notation is a user-friendly data format used in software development. It consists of key-value pairs and is commonly used for data exchange between servers and clients.

title: FTP
definition: FTP, or File Transfer Protocol, is a set of rules for how files should be shared over a network between client and server. It defines how users upload, download, and manage files on remote servers.

title: SFTP
definition: SFTP, or Secure File Transfer Protocol, is a network protocol like FTP, but more secure. It encrypts and authenticates data to protect it during transit using SSH keys.

title: MVC
definition: MVC is a software design pattern, often used in web development, that separates an application into three components: Model, View, and Controller.

title: PWA
definition: A Progressive Web Application uses HTML, CSS, and JS to create user-friendly experiences that mimic native apps through a web browser.

title: SDK
definition: A Software Development Kit contains tools for developers to use when building an application, which simplify or expedite the process.

title: SEO
definition: Search Engine Optimization encompasses a range of strategies and methods aimed at enhancing organic website traffic.

title: URL
definition: A Uniform Resource Locator is an address of a resource on the Internet, typically built up of a protocol, domain, and paths or parameters.
